title: GoPro holder for moondraker tracker r

description.text:
it is intended to be attached on the handlebar, it requires two M3 screws and a piece of rubber tape.
the rubber tape is meant to be placed on the interior of the holder that goes in contact with the handlebar to avoid scratches and absorb (some) vibrations :)
the holder is oriented 20 degrees on the left because the moondraker tracker r habdlebar is skewed.
it has been designed to be mounted on the right side of the handle bar.
designed with inventor 2014

To continue my earthquake preparation I made a wrench I can keep behind the Gas meter so I an shut it off @ the meter if a leak starts in the house.  
About $4.00 worth of ABS so it should be cheaper or close to the price of anything I could buy @ the home center.

This is a printable badge for judges at a show. It is a companion for the 1st place ribbon badges that can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24941 This was developed alongside an awesome local graphic designer Brett Sirianni from The Edge. Brett did the original 2D design, and I converted it into a 3D shape using blender.

Add a drive train to your old school Furby! Built for my 1 pound class combat robot ZUUL. (http://kitbuckley.net/?cat=16) More info in the Instructions section.

This chassis is designed to hold 2 Pololu micro metal gear motors (I personally went with the HP 30:1), 2 of my 16 tooth LEGO gear hubs for 3mm shafts (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:282352), 4 16 tooth LEGO gears, 2 LEGO pulley wheels, 2 short LEGO cross axles (3 or 4 "studs" long), and a 1/2" metal ball caster, also available from Pololu. The chassis has 4 holes to bolt it to an upper section; the spacing for these holes is 40mm x 70mm and they were designed with #6 machine screws in mind. Please note that the rear wheels are pretty far forward in this design (almost in the middle of the chassis) so when designing an upper section to hold batteries and other electronics, remember to keep the center of mass forward or be prepared to have a Furby that does awesome wheelies all the time. Bonus high-speed Furby test videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KF8OQmTjQYU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zvkyF81m-pM

comments.text:
for some reason, I can see me modifying it's voice so it says stuff like "Im going to kill you" and have it chase the annoying people off of my driveway with this. :P
Very neat design also.
comments.author: cae2100

title: Pully Center for Y-Axis Belt Guide

description.text:
I was wondering if the belt on the Y-Axis on my orca would stay on its bearing as there is no guide... It should work as other useres indicate, and i myself have been running it for quite a while.
As long as everything is perfectly aligned it will work. But, as the devil never sleeps and as i had one incident where it fell of i decided to make a snap on guide.

I suggest to use 2-3 Perimeters (including the outher shell) and give it some 40-50% infill (if you want you can make it even more solid).
Best if you Print 2 of this thing at the same time, one for front and one for back
Support is NOT NEEDED as all angles stay below or at max 30Â°.
Print and never skip :)

Using a Dial Gauge with 8mm diameter and mount this on the printhead low-end.
I was looking for fixing my Dial Gauge onto the printhead of my Ultimaker to level my bed - there are some thing's around here as the "Ultimaker Generic HeadMount" and then design a mounting part for my Dial Gauge.
The existing things for me where just to much to print - so I quickly created (in SolidEdge) this QuickFix for my DialGauge which has a diameter of 8mm (when you print this check for right fit -

I had to scale it by 1.05 in Cura to have an easy but fix position when sliding in the Gauge)
I drilled the small hole with 3mm to fit on the screw.
Use 2 nut's to fix this part in the right height on one of the long head-screws.

Have old PC and Commodore/Atari joysticks or flightsim controllers you wish you could use in your fancy new USB based computer? Wish no more! The Multijoy_Retro lets you use retro PC (15 pin) and Commodore/Atari (9 pin) joysticks directly in your new PC or Mac. Plug your retro stick in, flip some switches and it becomes either a keyboard, a mouse, or a joystick. Great for use with Dos BOX! Supports both the CH Flightstick and Thrustmaster FCS standards of hat switch encoding. Full details here: http://davenunez.wordpress.com/2014/04/06/creating-the-multijoy_retro/

This is a complex build requiring a Teensy++ 2.0 (http://www.pjrc.com/teensy/) as well as switches, potentiometers and the like. See full details here: http://davenunez.wordpress.com/2014/04/06/creating-the-multijoy_retro/

comments.text: Really nice design. Very retro. Your other work is really nice too. Thanks for sharing.
comments.author: ProgressTH

comments.text: awesome project and execution! I tried doing something similar a few years ago but used nes, snes, and psx/ps2 controllers instead, but eventually gave up on the project due to lack of time and other projects came up.
comments.author: cae2100

comments.text: Amazing! This puts the MAME arcade cabinet control panel I just finished building to shame! genius idea!
comments.author: Big-E

comments.text: Thanks Big-E! Appreciate the comment. The genesis/megadrive controller thing has always been a mixed bag in my experience, because while the three button controllers seem to work fine, the six button ones use a shift register that requires you to clock etc (which is a pain).
comments.author: Big-E

description.text:
In Holland we sell these candy strings. 
I Would love to try to feed them in to the Makerbot extruder and print my own candy!

comments.text: I am very into trying this as well!
comments.author: DaymakerLavon

comments.text: this would be awesome if it worked.
comments.author: The3DPrintist

comments.text: I've tried this and it did not work. This type of candy is made with flour and will not melt in the way we need. Test this by touching it to something hot and seeing if it melts. My testing was done with shoe string licorice from one store and does not preclude this from working with other candies.
comments.author: charlespax

comments.text: Every single time I walk past the "Old Fashioned Candy" display at the drug store, I see these and I wonder what would happen if you put them into a Makerbot extruder.
comments.author: VRAndy

comments.text:
That would be awfully messy with the normal extruder design.
Not sure what you would need to do to make such a thing work with candy "filament" but there are already sugar printers.
comments.author: ben_rockhold

comments.text: I agree but the sugar printers are more expensive than the normal ones.
comments.author: ben_rockhold
